comments:
build n0401, winxp, sun jdk 1.4.2

Note that this is with the nightly build and most likely fixed in HEAD but I
wanted to ensure that it was logged in case it has not been discovered yet.

- download the nightly build
- start eclipse
- get the following stack trace in the console
- all this is before the workspace launcher dialog is shown

I saw this too.  Although I was just running with the code from HEAD while self-
hosting.  I think it is an update.configurator problem.  If I import 
update.configurator from the I-Build into my self-hosting environment then the 
problem goes away.

This means that Update is reinstalling runtime and update.configurator during
the first startup.

Moving to Update for comments.

This is caused by Core/Equinox bug 51165:

The update configurator has some workaround code in a few places, and can add 
some more, but we should get the proper fix from the runtime.

What happens is that the bundles that are automatically started based on 
osgi.bundles entry, have a url of the form
reference:file:d:/some/path, but the bundles the configurator installs have 
the form
reference:file:/d:/some/path (note the leading / after file: )
which is consistent with java.io.File.toURL().
It appears that Platform.asLocalURL() and some other places in the runtime 
manually create these bundle url's as opposed to using the jdk to generate the 
url.
Moving to equinox for comments regarding the bundle url's.

ultimately  both URLs are correct and valid and indicate the same location.  We 
are pretty much damned if we do, damned if we don't.  There are bug reports 
floating around saying that we should NOT have the leading /.  here we are 
talking about adding a leading /.  I honestly don't know what the right answer 
is.  Consistency will help but is bound to make someone unhappy.  Thoughts?

moving this to update.  If update is going to test on location then it has to 
be prepared to get equivalent URLs which take different forms.  For exmaple, 
comparing file: URLs is best done by creating File objects and comparing them.

I think this particular problem has been fixed recently, but the general issue 
(comparing File's) is still valid.

Closing this, as we no longer log the install errors for automatically started 
bundles (such as osgi*, runtime, and update.configurator)

A bundle with the unique ID and version is a lready installed: org.eclipse.update.configurator 3.0.0
